tasks.task: Planting tomatoes indoors for outdoor garden
subtasks: Choose variety of tomatoes and plant two seeds each in red solo cups
Use halfway-filled containers (red solo cups) for seed starting
Keep soil moist by spraying vermiculite after planting
Create drainage holes at the bottom of containers
Remove first two leaves from seedlings for better root growth
Apply heat mat to speed up germination
Use plastic dome or cover to maintain humidity until germination
Turn on grow lights once seedlings germinate
Transplant seedlings to larger containers when ready for outdoor garden
Start other vegetables and flowers indoors simultaneously (if desired)
Manage limited space by keeping plants in original containers until transplant
Research and incorporate successful techniques from different growing zones (e.g., Brian from Next Level Gardening)
Consider variety of tomatoes (determinate, indeterminate, cherry, beefsteak) based on growing conditions and preference
Account for short outdoor growing season (appx. 110 days) when selecting tomato varieties and starting dates
Plant other short-season vegetables alongside tomatoes to maximize garden efficiency
Monitor and adjust watering, light, and temperature as seedlings grow from germination through transplant

tasks.task: Planting tomatoes indoors for the outdoor garden. Then the steps involved:
Planting tomatoes indoors for outdoor garden.
MAINTASK: Planting tomatoes indoors for the outdoor garden
subtasks: Choosing two seeds of each of seven tomato varieties
Preparing red solo cups by making drainage holes with scissors
Filling cups halfway with seed starting mix
Adding vermiculite on top of the mix and misting with water
Planting three seeds per cup
Covering seeds with vermiculite and ensuring adequate moisture
Using a heat mat to facilitate germination
Covering cups with a plastic dome to maintain humidity
Transitioning seedlings to grow lights once germinated
Removing the plastic cover as seedlings emerge
Trimming the first two leaves to promote root growth
